questions.question: What is the science that is defined as the study of the structure of the body?
questions.explanation: Anatomy is the science dedicated to the study of the structure of the body, both at a macroscopic and microscopic level.

questions.question: From what Greek term is the word 'anatomy' derived?
questions.explanation: The word 'anatomy' is derived from the Greek term 'anatomos', which is made up of the roots 'ana' (by means of) and 'tome' (cut).

questions.question: What branch of anatomy studies the development of the embryo and fetus?
questions.explanation: Embryology is the branch of anatomy specifically dedicated to the study of prenatal development, that is, of the embryo and fetus.

questions.question: What is the science that studies congenital malformations known?
questions.explanation: Teratology is the study of congenital malformations, a field related to developmental anatomy.

questions.question: In anatomical position, what direction does the term 'superior' indicate?
options: Towards the lower part of the body
Closest to the front of the body
Towards the highest part of the body
questions.explanation: The term superior indicates the direction towards the highest part of the body, also known as cranial or cephalic.

questions.question: What vertical cutting plane divides the body into anterior and posterior parts?
questions.explanation: The frontal or coronal plane is a vertical plane that cuts the median plane at right angles, dividing the body into anterior and posterior parts.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about anatomical position is correct?
options: The upper limbs are close to the body, with the palms of the hands facing back.
The palms of the hands face forward.
The feet are apart and pointing to the sides.
questions.explanation: The anatomical position is a convention in which the body is erect, the head and eyes face forward, and the palms of the hands are facing forward.

questions.question: Who was called the 'father of anatomy'?
questions.explanation: Herophilus of Chalcedon, who lived around 300 BC, has been recognized in history as the 'father of anatomy'.

questions.question: Who is known to be the 'founder of comparative anatomy'?
questions.explanation: Aristotle is considered the founder of comparative anatomy, an area of ​​knowledge that studies the similarities and differences in the anatomy of different species.

questions.question: In what century was the compound microscope invented?
questions.explanation: The compound microscope was invented by Zacarias Jansen in Holland around 1590, marking a milestone in the study of microscopic anatomy.

questions.question: What historical figure wrote 'De humani corporis fabrica', a fundamental work that reformed anatomy?
questions.explanation: Andrew Vesalius, an anatomist from Brussels, was the author of 'De humani corporis fabrica', a seminal work published in 1543 that changed the way human anatomy was studied and understood.

questions.question: What crucial event in the history of anatomy occurred in 1895?
questions.explanation: The discovery of X-rays by Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen in 1895 was a revolutionary advance that allowed the visualization of the internal structures of the human body.

questions.question: What is the main function of bones in the human body?
options: Protect vital organs and provide a framework
questions.explanation: Bones perform several vital functions, including protecting delicate organs such as the brain and heart, and forming a framework on which muscles are articulated, facilitating movement.

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the study of bones?
questions.explanation: Osteology is the term used to refer to the study of bones. The word derives from the Greek 'osteon' (bone) and 'logos' (treaty).

questions.question: How is the human skeleton divided?
questions.explanation: The skeleton is divided into two main parts: the axial skeleton, which includes the bones of the head, neck, and trunk, and the appendicular skeleton, which includes the bones of the limbs.

questions.question: What type of bone is characterized by having a length that predominates over its width and thickness?
questions.explanation: Long bones are those in which the length dimension is significantly greater than the other two. Examples of these bones are the femur and humerus.

questions.question: What technical name is given to the body or central portion of a long bone?
questions.explanation: The diaphysis is the technical name given to the tubular body of a long bone. It contains the medullary cavity and is composed of compact bone.

questions.question: What layer of tough connective tissue surrounds the shafts of long bones?
questions.explanation: The periosteum is a sheath of connective tissue that surrounds the diaphysis of long bones. It is formed by an external fibrous layer and an internal osteogenic layer.

questions.question: What are the bones found within the tendons or joint capsules known?
questions.explanation: The sesamoid bones are a variety of short bones that develop in the thickness of the tendons or joint capsules, mainly in the hands and feet.

questions.question: What is the name of the tough, elastic connective tissue that is part of many bones and skeletal elements?
questions.explanation: Cartilage is a connective tissue that, unlike bone, is resistant and elastic, composed of cells and fibers embedded in a firm intercellular matrix.

questions.question: Which of the following types of cartilage is the most abundant in the human body and is characterized by its translucent appearance?
questions.explanation: Hyaline cartilage is the most abundant type of cartilage in the human body and is named for its translucent or glass-like appearance due to the nature of its matrix.

questions.question: What type of joint joins bones together by fibrous tissue and allows little or no movement?
questions.explanation: Fibrous joints, sometimes called synarthroses, are those in which the bones are joined together by fibrous tissue, and with few exceptions, do not allow movement.

questions.question: What is the name of the thick, viscous fluid that fills the cavity of the synovial joints and whose main function is lubrication?
questions.explanation: Synovial fluid is the thick, viscous fluid found in synovial joints. It primarily acts as a lubricant to reduce friction between articular cartilage.

questions.question: What are synovial joints that are hinge-shaped and allow movement in a single plane called?
questions.explanation: The trochlear joints, also known as hinge or ginglimus joints, are uniaxial and allow movement in a single plane, such as flexion and extension.

questions.question: Which of the following joints is an example of a bicondylar joint?
questions.explanation: The knee is an example of a bicondylar joint, which is made up of two independent articular surfaces called condyles.

questions.question: What term is used to describe the motion of a limb in which it rotates around a cone?
questions.explanation: Circumduction is a combined movement that is performed in joints such as the shoulder, where the limb rotates describing the shape of a cone.

questions.question: What fundamental substance does the synovial membrane produce that differentiates it from other connective tissues?
questions.explanation: The synovial membrane is distinguished from other connective tissues in that it produces a ground substance that is a liquid rather than a gel.

questions.question: What component of synovial fluid is responsible for its viscosity?
questions.explanation: The viscosity of synovial fluid is almost entirely due to the presence of the non-sulfated mucopolysaccharide known as hyaluronic acid.

questions.question: How are joints classified according to their most notable structural characteristics?
questions.explanation: Joints are classified into three main types based on their structural characteristics: fibrous, cartilaginous and synovial.

questions.question: In what type of fibrous joint are the bones of the skull joined together by several layers of fibers?
questions.explanation: Sutures are fibrous joints where the bones of the skull are joined together by several layers of fibers.

questions.question: What is the name of joints with hyaline cartilage that are temporary unions and act as growth zones?
questions.explanation: Joints with hyaline cartilage are temporary junctions sometimes called primary cartilaginous joints or synchondroses, and act as growth zones.

questions.question: What is the main function of intra-articular discs and menisci?
questions.explanation: Intra-articular menisci and discs help spread synovial fluid to lubricate the joint while helping to prevent instability.

questions.question: What type of nerve fibers are very sensitive to position and movement and are found in the capsule and ligaments?
questions.explanation: Some sensory fibers in the capsule and ligaments form proprioceptive endings, which are very sensitive to joint position and movement.

questions.question: What type of cartilage resembles hyaline cartilage, but differs in having elastic fibers and rarely calcifies?
questions.explanation: Elastic cartilage is a type of cartilage that looks like hyaline, but its fibers are elastic and it rarely calcifies over the years.

questions.question: What is arthrology?
questions.explanation: Arthrology is the term used to refer to the study of joints, originating from the Greek root 'arthron'.

questions.question: What is the name of the fibrous joint that joins the tooth to its socket?
questions.explanation: The alveolantary joint, which joins the tooth to its socket, is called gomphosis and is sometimes classified as a third type of fibrous joint.

questions.question: What type of synovial joint allows movements in three axes and an example of this is the shoulder joint?
questions.explanation: Enarthroses, also known as ball joints, allow movements around three axes and examples of them are the shoulder and hip joints.

questions.question: What type of movement occurs when the articular surfaces of the bones of the arthrodia slide or move over each other?
questions.explanation: Arthrodia, or flat joints, allow one bone to slide or move over another in any direction.

questions.question: What is the usual cause of noises in the joints, such as those made when pulling the fingers sharply?
options: Presence of air in the joint
Formation of a partial vacuum in the joint cavity
questions.explanation: Joint sounds, such as clicking when straightening the fingers, are due to the sudden formation of a partial vacuum in the joint cavity when the surfaces are pulled apart.

questions.question: What type of joint is the symphysis pubis and those found between the vertebral bodies?
questions.explanation: The symphysis pubis and the joints between the vertebral bodies are examples of joints with fibrocartilage, also known as secondary cartilaginous joints or amphiarthroses.

questions.question: What is the main function of fascia, other than being a packing material?
options: Serve as insertion points for muscles
Facilitate the transmission of nerve impulses
questions.explanation: Fascia is a connective tissue material that, among its multiple functions, serves as insertion points for muscles and an elastic sheath for them.

questions.question: How are the two subdivisions of the brain divided, which in turn are divided into telencephalon and diencephalon, and metencephalon and myelencephalon, respectively?
questions.explanation: The brain is divided into forebrain, midbrain and hindbrain. The forebrain has two subdivisions, telencephalon and diencephalon, while the hindbrain has two subdivisions, metencephalon and myelencephalon.

questions.question: What part of the central nervous system is made up of millions of neurons and glial cells?
questions.explanation: The central nervous system is made up of the brain and spinal cord. This part is made up of millions of neurons and glial cells, along with blood vessels and connective tissue.

questions.question: What does cerebrospinal fluid protect?
questions.explanation: Cerebrospinal fluid, found in the ventricles of the brain and the subarachnoid space, protects the brain and helps reduce damage from trauma.

questions.question: What is the function of the bundles that ascend and descend through the brain and spinal cord?
options: Connect to cells located at different levels
questions.explanation: The white matter of the spinal cord and brain contains bundles that ascend to or descend from the brain, and others that connect cells located at different levels of the spinal cord.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a true peripheral nerve, but rather a bundle of the central nervous system?
questions.explanation: The optic nerve is not considered a true peripheral nerve, but rather a bundle of the central nervous system.

questions.question: What are plexuses in the peripheral nervous system?
options: Branches that innervate the skin of the back
Autonomous ganglia in the brain stem
Masses of gray matter inside the brain
Intermingling of anterior branches of the spinal nerves
questions.explanation: In the cervical and lumbosacral regions, the anterior branches of the spinal nerves intermingle to form plexuses, from which the main peripheral nerves originate.

questions.question: How many pairs of spinal nerves are there in general?
questions.explanation: Generally, there are 31 pairs of spinal nerves: eight cervical, twelve thoracic, five lumbar, five sacral, and one coccygeal.

questions.question: What type of nerve fibers stimulate or activate skeletal muscle?
questions.explanation: The fibers that have the function of stimulating or activating skeletal muscle are called motor or efferent fibers.

questions.question: What is a dermatome?
options: The area of ​​skin supplied by a single peripheral nerve
A mass of nervous tissue in the brain
A sheath of connective tissue that surrounds a nerve
The area of ​​skin innervated by the sensory fibers of a single posterior root
questions.explanation: A dermatome is the area of ​​skin that receives its sensory innervation from a single posterior root of a spinal nerve.

questions.question: What is the main function of the cerebellum?
questions.explanation: The cerebellum is an organ of the nervous system that plays a crucial role in the automatic regulation of movement and maintenance of posture.

questions.question: Where is the gray matter located in the spinal cord?
questions.explanation: In the spinal cord, the gray matter is located in the inner part, surrounded by the white matter, which contrasts with its location in the brain.

questions.question: Which of the following meninges is closest to the brain and spinal cord?
questions.explanation: The brain and spinal cord are protected by the meninges, which from the outside in are the dura mater, the arachnoid mater, and the pia mater. The pia mater is the innermost layer, directly over the nervous tissue.

questions.question: What part of the autonomic nervous system includes the fibers originating from the brain stem and sacral segments of the spinal cord?
questions.explanation: The parasympathetic system, also known as the craniosacral division of the autonomic system, is made up of preganglionic fibers that originate in the brain stem and sacral segments of the spinal cord.

questions.question: What is reticular formation?
options: A group of nuclei in the cerebellum
A diffuse mixture of gray and white matter in the brain stem
A bundle of fibers that connect the spinal cord and thalamus
A type of ganglion in the spinal cord
questions.explanation: The reticular formation is a notable feature of the brain stem, described as a diffuse mixture of gray and white matter extending along the brain stem.

questions.question: What does the connective tissue sheath of the endoneurium contain?
questions.explanation: The connective tissue sheath of the endoneurium gives great resistance to the nerve and contains the blood vessels that provide its blood supply.

questions.question: What effect does cutting a single peripheral nerve have?
options: Loss of sensation in a diffuse area
questions.explanation: Cutting a peripheral nerve produces marked weakness or even total paralysis of the muscles it innervates, as well as total loss of sensitivity in a specific area.

questions.question: What are the sheets of non-nervous tissue that surround and protect the brain and spinal cord called?
questions.explanation: The brain and spinal cord are enveloped and protected by layers of non-nervous tissue called meninges. These include the dura mater, the arachnoid mater, and the pia mater.

questions.question: What is the main function of sweat glands?
options: Help in the digestion of food
questions.explanation: Sweat glands regulate body temperature through perspiration, as the evaporation of water extracts heat from the body.

questions.question: Which layer of the skin contains melanin, the pigment that protects from ultraviolet light?
questions.explanation: Melanin, which protects the body from ultraviolet light, is located mainly in the basal layer of the epidermis.

questions.question: What is meant by 'viscera'?
options: The internal organs of the body
questions.explanation: The viscera are the internal organs of the body, most located in the thoracic, abdominal and pelvic cavities.

questions.question: What is the main function of the kidneys?
options: Maintain the ionic balance of the blood
Filter the air that enters the lungs
questions.explanation: The kidneys are the most important excretory organs, responsible for maintaining the ionic balance of the blood and eliminating waste products.

questions.question: What part of the skin is avascular and acts as a semipermeable barrier?
questions.explanation: The epidermis is an avascular layer of stratified squamous epithelium that acts as a barrier to the passage of water.

questions.question: What is the name of the thin fold of soft keratin that covers the root of the nail?
questions.explanation: The eponychium is the extension of the stratum corneum of the skin that grows over the root of the nail.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an organ of the digestive system?
questions.explanation: The kidneys belong to the urinary system, while the others are part of the digestive system or its accessory glands.

questions.question: Which organ of the male reproductive systems serves as a passageway for both urine and seminal fluid?
questions.explanation: The urethra in men is the only organ of the urogenital system that serves for the passage of urine and seminal fluid.

questions.question: What name is given to the nervous plexus that is located in the muscular envelope of the hollow organs?
questions.explanation: The myenteric plexus is composed of nerve cells and fibers that are located in the muscular envelope of hollow organs.

questions.question: Which of the following glands is classified as holocrine, since its secretory cells disintegrate in the secretion process?
questions.explanation: The sebaceous glands are holocrine type, which means that their secretory cells disintegrate to release their secretion (sebum).

questions.question: What is the layer of connective tissue that gives strength to the wall of a hollow tubular organ?
questions.explanation: The submucosa is the layer that consists of loose connective tissue and is what gives strength to the wall of the hollow organ.

questions.question: What part of the respiratory system is made up of the lungs and the intrapulmonary ducts, where gas exchange occurs?
questions.explanation: The respiratory portion of the respiratory system is made up of the lungs and intrapulmonary ducts, where carbon dioxide is exchanged for oxygen.

questions.question: What is the name given to the combination of skin, subcutaneous tissue, hair, nails and mammary gland?
questions.explanation: The term 'tegument' is used to designate the group formed by the skin and subcutaneous tissue, hair, nails and the mammary gland.

questions.question: What skin structure causes 'goosebumps' to contract?
questions.explanation: The arrector pili muscle extends from the hair follicle to the dermis, and its contraction makes the hair erect, causing the 'gooseflesh' appearance.

questions.question: What is the function of the arrector pili muscle?
options: Making hair erect in response to emotions or cold
Produce sebum to lubricate the skin
questions.explanation: The arrector pili muscle contracts in response to emotions or cold, causing the hair to stand erect.

questions.question: What name are given to the lines of thickened epidermis on the palm of the hand and sole of the foot that are used for individual identification?
questions.explanation: Papillary ridges are lines of thickened epidermis that form a characteristic and persistent pattern on the palm of the hand and sole of the foot, used for fingerprints.

questions.question: What happens to water in the large intestine?
options: It is secreted to aid in digestion
questions.explanation: Water is absorbed through the wall of the large intestine, which also drives waste products for elimination.

questions.question: Where does oocyte fertilization normally occur in the female reproductive system?
questions.explanation: Fertilization of the oocyte, if it occurs, usually takes place inside one of the uterine tubes.

questions.question: Which layer of skin consists of a superficial papillary layer and a deep reticular layer?
questions.explanation: The dermis, or chorion, consists of a superficial papillary layer and a deep reticular layer, which is the thickest.

questions.question: Which of the following is a function of the skin?
questions.explanation: The skin provides the body with a waterproof protective covering, helps regulate temperature, and contains sensitive nerve endings.

questions.question: What property of X-rays allows them to pass through solid matter?
questions.explanation: The penetrating effect is the property of X-rays to pass through solid matter. Those with shorter wavelengths have greater penetration power.

questions.question: Based on its radiopacity, which structure is the most radiolucent?
questions.explanation: Air is the structure with the lowest density, therefore, it is the most radiolucent and appears darkest on an x-ray.

questions.question: How are structures that are difficult to penetrate by X-rays classified?
questions.explanation: Structures that are difficult or not penetrated by X-rays are described as radiopaque.

questions.question: What is the principle of computed axial tomography (CAT) based on?
options: A thin beam of x-rays that moves through the body
The emission of light through metallic salts
Positive electrostatic charges on a selenium surface
questions.explanation: CT scan uses an X-ray tube that emits a thin beam to scan the body, and the tissue density data is processed by a computer to reconstruct a cross-sectional image.

questions.question: What is the main bone of the arm?
questions.explanation: The humerus is the bone that forms the main structure of the arm, articulating with the scapula above and with the ulna and radius below.

questions.question: In ultrasonography, what type of radiation is used to create the image?
questions.explanation: Ultrasonography does not use ionizing radiation, but rather relies on the use of high-frequency sound waves to generate echoes that are recorded and displayed as an image.

questions.question: What part of the clavicle is concave forward?
questions.explanation: The outer third of the clavicle is concave forward, while the inner two thirds are convex.

questions.question: How is the radiographic appearance of compact bone described?
options: A homogeneous band of calcareous density
questions.explanation: Compact bone is seen on radiographs as a homogeneous band of calcareous density, often at the periphery of the bone.

questions.question: What term describes a technique in which an x-ray of a structure is taken at a given depth, blurring the surrounding planes?
questions.explanation: Tomography is a radiographic study in which the tube and the film rotate in opposite directions during exposure, achieving the erasure of tissue planes other than that of the structure of interest.

questions.question: What is the reason for the high degree of radiopacity of the skeleton?
options: Its high calcium and phosphorus content
questions.explanation: The skeleton has a high degree of radiopacity due to its calcium and phosphorus content, which makes it absorb X-rays more easily than other tissues.

questions.question: What is the xeroradiography method based on?
options: In the use of sound waves
In the absorption of light by metallic salts
In the detection of selenium fluorescence
In the loss of electrostatic charge on a selenium surface
questions.explanation: Xeroradiography is based on the principle of xerography, where an electrostatically charged selenium surface loses charge when exposed to x-rays passing through tissues.

questions.question: What structure joins the trunk to the upper limb, articulating with the manubrium of the sternum and the acromion of the scapula?
questions.explanation: The clavicle is the long bone that extends from the manubrium of the sternum to the acromion of the scapula, thus uniting the trunk with the upper limb.

questions.question: On an x-ray, which space is almost completely occupied by articular cartilage?
questions.explanation: The radiological joint space is the space between the epiphyseal regions of two bones and is almost completely occupied by the layers of articular cartilage.

questions.question: Which method allows the radiologist to observe the movement of body parts and change the subject's position during the examination?
questions.explanation: The main advantages of fluoroscopy are the ease of observing the movements of the subject's parts and the possibility of modifying their position during the examination.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a segment of the upper limb?
questions.explanation: The upper limb is divided into four segments: shoulder girdle, arm, forearm and hand. The thigh is part of the lower limb.

questions.question: How is cancellous bone described on x-rays?
options: A homogeneous band of calcareous density
A network of calcareous density with interstices of soft tissue density
A surface with a positive electrostatic charge
questions.explanation: On x-rays, cancellous bone appears as a network of calcareous density with interstices that have the density of soft tissues.

questions.question: Which radiographic procedure is taken in two positions perpendicular to each other to give a best impression of depth?
questions.explanation: In many regions, films are taken in two positions perpendicular to each other to give a better impression of depth; this procedure is known as biplane radiography.

questions.question: What contrast medium can be injected into blood vessels to visualize organs such as the gallbladder?
questions.explanation: An organic iodinated compound can be injected intravenously to visualize the gallbladder, as organic iodinated compounds can be injected into blood vessels.

questions.question: What type of x-rays are known as 'hard rays'?
options: Those that do not have penetrating effect
Those that produce a fluorescent effect
questions.explanation: Shorter wavelength X-rays have greater penetrating power and are known as 'hard rays'.

questions.question: What is the name of the bone of the forearm that articulates with the bones of the carpus, or wrist?
questions.explanation: The radius is the bone of the forearm that articulates directly with the bones of the carpus, or wrist.

questions.question: What is the bone that makes up the upper arm?
questions.explanation: The humerus is the longest and most robust bone of the upper limb, located between the shoulder and the elbow.

questions.question: What anatomical structure is commonly known as the scapula?
questions.explanation: The scapula is a flat, triangular bone located at the back of the shoulder and connects the humerus to the clavicle.

questions.question: What muscle is located on the back of the thigh and is responsible for knee flexion?
questions.explanation: The hamstrings are a group of muscles that include the biceps femoris, semitendinosus, and semimembranosus, whose main function is knee flexion and hip extension.

questions.question: Which of the following is a skull bone?
questions.explanation: The temporal bone is one of the paired bones of the skull that forms part of the base and sides of the skull, where the ear is housed.

questions.question: What type of joint allows movement in multiple directions, such as the shoulder joint?
questions.explanation: The ball and socket joint, also known as enarthrosis, is a synovial joint in which the ball and socket surface of one bone fits into the cavity of another, allowing a large range of motion.

questions.question: What name is given to the process of bone tissue formation?
questions.explanation: Ossification is the process by which cartilage turns into bone during fetal development and subsequent growth.

questions.question: What cavity is the concave surface of the scapula where the humerus articulates?
questions.explanation: The glenoid cavity is the concave fossa of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus to form the shoulder joint.

questions.question: What is the muscle that forms the main mass of the calf and helps with plantar flexion?
questions.explanation: The soleus muscle, together with the gastrocnemius, forms the triceps surae muscle in the calf and is essential for plantar flexion of the foot.

questions.question: What bone is the main component of the spine?
questions.explanation: Vertebrae are the 33 individual bones that stack together to form the vertebral column, protecting the spinal cord.

questions.question: What structure connects bone to muscle?
questions.explanation: Tendons are bands of fibrous connective tissue that connect muscles to bones, allowing movement.

questions.question: What bone is known as the 'Adam's apple'?
questions.explanation: The 'Adam's apple' is the prominence formed by the thyroid cartilage, the largest cartilage of the larynx.

questions.question: What part of the nervous system controls voluntary body movements?
questions.explanation: The somatic nervous system is responsible for voluntary bodily functions, including the movement of skeletal muscles.

questions.question: What major artery supplies the lower body and legs?
questions.explanation: The femoral artery is the main artery that supplies the lower limb, carrying oxygenated blood to the muscles of the thigh.

questions.question: What organ produces bile, which helps in the digestion of fats?
questions.explanation: The liver is the organ responsible for producing bile, a substance that emulsifies fats in the small intestine for absorption.

questions.question: What is the main function of red blood cells?
questions.explanation: Red blood cells (erythrocytes) contain hemoglobin, a protein that binds to oxygen and transports it from the lungs to the rest of the body.

questions.question: What part of the heart pumps blood to the rest of the body?
questions.explanation: The left ventricle is the strongest chamber of the heart and is responsible for pumping oxygenated blood through the aorta to the rest of the body.

questions.question: Which bone is a major component of the forearm and is on the thumb side?
questions.explanation: The radius is one of the two bones of the forearm and is located on the lateral side, which corresponds to the position of the thumb.

questions.question: What system is responsible for the production of hormones to regulate bodily functions?
questions.explanation: The endocrine system is made up of glands that secrete hormones to control and coordinate various functions in the body, such as growth and metabolism.

questions.question: What structure protects the spinal cord?
questions.explanation: The vertebral column, made up of a series of vertebrae, forms a bony canal that protects the delicate spinal cord.

questions.question: What is the main organ of the respiratory system, responsible for gas exchange?
questions.explanation: The lungs are the primary organs of respiration. In the alveoli, which are located inside the lungs, the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide occurs.

questions.question: What is the most frequently fractured carpal bone?
questions.explanation: The scaphoid is the most frequently fractured carpal bone, often from a fall onto the outstretched hand.

questions.question: Which bone is the smallest of the carpal bones and the last to ossify?
questions.explanation: The pisiform is considered the smallest of the carpal bones and is the last to undergo the ossification process.

questions.question: The eight carpal bones are arranged in two rows. What are the bones of the distal row, from outside to inside?
options: Trapezius, trapezoid, capitate bone and hook bone
Large, hooked, trapezoid and trapezoid bone
questions.explanation: The distal row of the carpus, from outside to inside, is composed of the trapezius, the trapezoid, the capitate (capitatum), and the hook bone (hamatum).

questions.question: What ligament maintains the concavity of the carpus and forms the roof of the carpal tunnel?
options: The anterior annular ligament of the carpus
questions.explanation: The anterior annular ligament of the carpus, also known as the flexor retinaculum, forms the roof of the osteofibrous tunnel through which the flexor tendons pass.

questions.question: Which of the following carpal bones aligns with the third metacarpal?
questions.explanation: The capitate (capitatum) aligns directly with the third metacarpal.

questions.question: What bones make up the floor of the 'anatomical snuffbox'?
options: The pyramidal and the large bone
questions.explanation: The scaphoid and trapezius are the bones found on the floor of the 'anatomical snuff box', an area where pain occurs when the scaphoid is fractured.

questions.question: Which bone is the largest of the carpal bones and the first to ossify?
questions.explanation: The capitate bone is the largest of the carpal bones and, along with the hook bone, is one of the first to ossify.

questions.question: How many phalanges does the thumb have compared to the other fingers?
options: Two, while the other fingers have three
Three, while the other fingers have two
questions.explanation: Each finger has three phalanges, with the exception of the thumb, which only has two.

questions.question: What are the most notable superficial veins that ascend from the dorsal venous network of the hand?
options: The subclavian vein and the axillary vein
The jugular vein and the subclavian vein
The cephalic vein and the basilic vein
The humeral vein and the axillary vein
questions.explanation: From the dorsal venous network of the hand, the cephalic vein and the basilic vein ascend, which are the most notable among the superficial veins.

questions.question: What anastomotic vein connects the cephalic and basilic veins on the anterior aspect of the elbow?
options: The median vein of the forearm
questions.explanation: The median ulnar vein is an anastomotic vein that runs upward and inward, connecting the cephalic vein and the basilic vein at the elbow.

questions.question: According to the ossification process, which epiphyseal center of the ulna develops first?
options: The center of the proximal epiphysis
The center of the distal epiphysis
Both develop at the same time
questions.explanation: The centers for the proximal and distal epiphyses of the ulna develop during childhood, but that for the distal epiphysis appears first.

questions.question: The posterior surface of the ulna is divided by a longitudinal ridge into two parts. Which of them is covered by the posterior ulnaris?
questions.explanation: A longitudinal ridge divides the posterior surface of the ulna into a smooth internal part, which is covered by the posterior ulnar muscle, and a rough external part for muscular insertions.

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of the distal phalanx?
questions.explanation: The distal phalanges are characterized by having nail tuberosities, which are rough expansions on their distal epiphyses.

questions.question: Which carpal bone is easily identified by its prominent hook or uncinate process?
questions.explanation: The hooked bone (hamatum) is identified by its uncinate process, which is palpable and prominent on its palmar aspect.

questions.question: What is the base of the proximal phalanx articulated with?
options: With the head of the middle phalanx
With the head of the corresponding metacarpal bone
With the diaphysis of the middle phalanx
questions.explanation: The base of the proximal phalanx has a rounded and concave facet that articulates with the head of the corresponding metacarpal bone.

questions.question: Which carpal bones form a concavity that houses the head of the capitate bone and the hook bone?
options: The trapezius, the trapezoid and the pisiform
questions.explanation: The hook bone and the head of the capitate occupy a concavity formed by the scaphoid, lunate and piriformis.

questions.question: What veins accompany most of the arteries of the upper limb and usually occur in pairs?
questions.explanation: The deep veins, with the exception of the axillary vein, usually occur in pairs with transverse connections and are called satellite veins.

questions.question: What characteristic distinguishes the distal surface of the distal phalanx?
questions.explanation: The distal phalanx is characterized by having a rough expansion at its distal epiphysis, called the nail tuberosity, which is more prominent on the anterior surface.

questions.question: Which bone is the shortest of the metacarpals?
options: The fifth metacarpal (of the little finger)
questions.explanation: The first metacarpal, which corresponds to the thumb, is the shortest of the metacarpal bones.

questions.question: What structures make up the knuckles of the fingers?
options: The heads of the proximal and middle phalanges
questions.explanation: The knuckles of the fingers are formed by the heads of the proximal and middle phalanges.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles of the pectoral region is the only one that inserts into the humerus?
questions.explanation: The pectoralis major muscle is inserted by means of a bilaminar tendon on the outer lip of the bicipital canal of the humerus, unlike the other muscles of the pectoral region which do so on the shoulder girdle.

questions.question: Which axillary fold is formed by the lower border of the pectoralis major muscle?
questions.explanation: The rounded lower edge of the pectoralis major is responsible for forming the anterior axillary fold.

questions.question: What is the main action of the serratus major muscle?
options: Rotate the scapula and pull it forward
questions.explanation: The serratus major is a powerful muscle that rotates the scapula so that the inferior angle moves outward, which is crucial for abduction and elevation of the arm. It also pulls the scapula forward in acts such as throwing and pushing.

questions.question: Paralysis of which muscle is characterized by the 'wing of the scapula' appearance?
questions.explanation: Paralysis of the serratus major manifests itself with 'winged scapula', where the inner edge of the scapula separates from the chest wall, making it almost impossible to raise the arm above the horizontal.

questions.question: What superficial muscles of the back insert into the humerus?
questions.explanation: Of the superficial muscles of the back, only the latissimus dorsi inserts into the humerus, while the others insert into the shoulder girdle.

questions.question: What is the main function of the latissimus dorsi muscle?
options: Adduction and extension of the arm
questions.explanation: The latissimus dorsi is a powerful adductor and extensor of the arm. It is important in movements such as swimming, rowing, climbing and hammering.

questions.question: Which of the following nerves supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle?
questions.explanation: The latissimus dorsi muscle is specifically innervated by the latissimus dorsi nerve, also known as the thoracodorsal nerve.

questions.question: What structure forms in the space between the outer edge of the trapezius, the upper edge of the latissimus dorsi, and the inner edge of the scapula?
questions.explanation: This space, whose floor is formed by the rhomboid major, is called the auscultation triangle.

questions.question: What muscle is primarily responsible for arm abduction?
questions.explanation: The middle or acromial portion of the deltoid muscle is a powerful abductor of the arm, whose contraction produces elevation of the arm in the plane of the scapula.

questions.question: What nerve innervates the deltoid muscle?
questions.explanation: The deltoid is innervated by the circumflex nerve, also known as the axillary nerve.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles is NOT part of the rotator cuff?
questions.explanation: The muscles that make up the rotator cuff are the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor and subscapularis. The teres major is an adductor and extensor of the arm that forms the posterior wall of the armpit, but is not part of the rotator cuff.

questions.question: What is the main action of the supraspinatus muscle?
options: Assist the deltoid in arm abduction
questions.explanation: The supraspinatus muscle, along with the deltoid, contracts simultaneously to initiate arm abduction.

questions.question: What nerve innervates the teres minor muscle?
questions.explanation: Although the infraspinatus is innervated by the suprascapular nerve, the teres minor is innervated by the circumflex nerve, as is the deltoid.

questions.question: What muscle is part of the posterior wall of the armpit, along with the latissimus dorsi and teres major?
questions.explanation: The posterior wall of the armpit is formed by the subscapularis, teres major, and latissimus dorsi.

questions.question: What is the main content of the humerotricipital (quadrilateral) space?
options: Scapular branches of the subscapular artery
Circumflex nerve and posterior humeral circumflex vessels
Radial nerve and deep brachial artery
questions.explanation: The humerotricipital space, which is located between the teres minor and major muscles, the triceps and the humerus, gives way to the circumflex nerve and the posterior humeral circumflex vessels.

questions.question: What spinal nerves contribute to the formation of the brachial plexus?
questions.explanation: The brachial plexus is formed by the union of the anterior branches of the last four cervical nerves (C5, C6, C7 and C8) and most of the anterior branch of the first dorsal nerve (D1).

questions.question: What primary trunk of the brachial plexus is formed by the union of the branches of C8 and D1?
questions.explanation: The branches of the C8 and D1 nerves join to form the lower primary trunk of the brachial plexus.

questions.question: The clavipectoral fascia fuses outward with which process?
questions.explanation: Outwardly, the clavipectoral fascia extends to the coracoid process, where it joins other fascias and ligaments.

questions.question: Which muscle of the pectoral region originates from the anterior aspect of the second to fifth ribs?
questions.explanation: The pectoralis minor muscle originates on the anterior surface of the second to fifth ribs and inserts on the coracoid process.

questions.question: What muscle is a powerful inward rotator of the arm?
questions.explanation: The subscapularis is a powerful inward rotator of the arm and helps support the head of the humerus in the glenoid.

questions.question: What is the thickest branch of the third portion of the axillary artery?
questions.explanation: The subscapular artery is the thickest branch of the third portion of the axillary artery and descends along the outer edge of the scapula.

questions.question: What nerve accompanies the internal or thoracic branch of the subscapular artery?
questions.explanation: The internal or thoracic branch of the subscapular artery, also known as the thoracodorsal artery, accompanies the latissimus dorsi nerve.

questions.question: Which artery becomes the brachial artery as it passes the inferior border of the teres major muscle?
questions.explanation: The axillary artery changes name to become the brachial artery when it leaves the inferior border of the teres major muscle.

questions.question: Which ligament bridges the bicipital canal and holds the biceps tendon in place?
questions.explanation: The transverse humeral ligament forms a bridge over the bicipital canal and is responsible for holding the biceps tendon in position.

questions.question: What muscles act as the main flexors of the arm?
options: Pectoralis major (clavicular portion) and deltoid (anterior portion)
questions.explanation: The main flexors of the arm are the clavicular portion of the pectoralis major and the anterior portion of the deltoid, with the help of the coracobrachialis and the biceps.

questions.question: What type of joint is the glenohumeral joint of the shoulder?
questions.explanation: The glenohumeral joint, or shoulder joint, is classified as an osteoarthritis, which allows it great freedom of movement.

questions.question: What is the function of the coracoacromial ligament?
options: Form a protective roof over the supraspinatus tendon and the head of the humerus
Provide stability to the sternoclavicular joint
Attach the clavicle to the first costal cartilage
questions.explanation: The coracoacromial ligament, together with the acromion and coracoid process, forms a protective arch or roof over the supraspinatus tendon and the head of the humerus.

questions.question: What nerves innervate the shoulder joint?
options: Musculocutaneous and internal cutaneous brachial nerves
Circumflex, suprascapular and pectoralis major nerves
questions.explanation: The shoulder joint is innervated by the circumflex, suprascapular, and pectoralis major nerves, as well as by the posterior secondary trunk of the brachial plexus and sympathetic fibers.

questions.question: What muscles are the main external rotators of the humerus?
questions.explanation: The main external rotator muscles of the humerus are the infraspinatus and the teres minor, assisted by the posterior portion of the deltoid.

questions.question: What anatomical structure is located between the supraspinatus and deltoid tendons, functioning as a lubrication mechanism?
options: The transverse ligament of the scapula
questions.explanation: The subdeltoid serous bursa is located between the supraspinatus and deltoid tendons, acting as a lubrication mechanism during movement of the shoulder joint.

questions.question: What is the main function of the coracoclavicular ligament?
options: Form an opening for the suprascapular nerve
Keeping the clavicle in place when the trapezius is inactive
Attach the humerus to the glenoid cavity
questions.explanation: The coracoclavicular ligament, composed of the conoid and trapezoid ligaments, is a strong fibrous band that reinforces the acromioclavicular joint.

questions.question: What structures make up the coracoacromial arch?
options: The clavicle, acromion, and coracoclavicular ligament
The coracoid process, clavicle, and transverse humeral ligament
The acromion, coracoid process, and coracoacromial ligament
The glenoid labrum and fibrous capsule
questions.explanation: The coracoacromial arch is formed by the acromion, the coracoid process, and the coracoacromial ligament.

questions.question: What is the main abductor of the arm?
questions.explanation: The main abductor of the arm is the deltoid, which is assisted by the supraspinatus.

questions.question: What joint is formed between the inner end of the clavicle, the sternum, and the first costal cartilage?
questions.explanation: The sternoclavicular joint is formed by the union of the inner end of the clavicle, the sternum, and the first costal cartilage.

questions.question: How is shoulder abduction movement defined?
options: Movement backward and outward, away from the chest.
Movement forward and inward, crossing the anterior surface of the thorax.
The humerus rotates around its long axis.
Movement forward and outward, away from the trunk.
questions.explanation: Arm abduction is defined as movement forward and outward, away from the trunk.

questions.question: What ligament extends over the coracoid notch and makes it an opening for the suprascapular nerve?
questions.explanation: The coracoid ligament, also known as the superior transverse ligament of the scapula, passes over the coracoid notch and forms an opening for the suprascapular nerve.

questions.question: What is the smallest and most variable branch of the first portion of the axillary artery?
questions.explanation: The superior thoracic artery is a small, variable branch of the first portion of the axillary artery that supplies adjacent muscles.

questions.question: What muscles are the main adductors against resistance?
options: Pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi and teres major
questions.explanation: The main adductors of the arm against resistance are the pectoralis major, the latissimus dorsi, and the teres major.

questions.question: What veins join to form the axillary vein?
options: Internal jugular vein and subclavian vein
Thoracoepigastric veins and superior vena cava
questions.explanation: The axillary vein begins at the inferior border of the teres major, where the basilic vein joins the humeral veins.

questions.question: Which ligament primarily prevents the acromion from sliding below the clavicle in a fall on the extended hand?
questions.explanation: The trapezoid ligament, which has a horizontal direction, mainly prevents the acromion from sliding below the clavicle in a fall on the extended hand.

questions.question: What are the main movements in the elbow joint?
questions.explanation: The movements at the elbow joint are flexion and extension. Pronation and supination occur between the radius and ulna.

questions.question: What nerve primarily innervates the anterior flexor muscle group of the forearm?
questions.explanation: The superficial flexor muscle group originates primarily from the anterior aspect of the epitrochlea and is innervated by the median nerve, while the deep group receives most of its innervation from the anterior interosseous nerve, which is a branch of the median.

questions.question: What muscle is considered the main pronator of the forearm?
questions.explanation: The main pronator is the pronator quadratus, assisted by the pronator teres during rapid movement or against resistance.

questions.question: What is the main supinator of the forearm, assisted by the biceps?
questions.explanation: The short supinator is the main supinator, assisted by the biceps during rapid movement or against resistance.

questions.question: Which of the following forearm flexor muscles inserts at the base of the second and third metacarpals?
questions.explanation: The Palmar major attaches to the anterior surface of the base of the second and third metacarpals.

questions.question: What extensor muscle inserts into the tubercle of the inner surface of the base of the fifth metacarpal?
questions.explanation: The posterior ulnar inserts into a tubercle on the inner surface of the base of the fifth metacarpal.

questions.question: The tendon of the Palmar minor muscle inserts into the anterior annular ligament of the carpus and into the apex of the palmar aponeurosis. What notable feature does this muscle have?
options: It is the strongest of the hand flexors
It is the only muscle of the forearm innervated by the ulnar nerve.
Acts as the main supinator of the hand
questions.explanation: The palmaris minor muscle is frequently missing, which is a fact that is related to the side of the body, sex and race.

questions.question: What is the main action of the flexor digitorum profundus muscle?
questions.explanation: The flexor digitorum profundus flexes the distal phalanges over the middle ones, and its tendons give rise to the lumbrical muscles in the palm of the hand.

questions.question: The muscles of the forearm are divided into an anterior and a posterior group. What type of muscles are found in the posterior group?
questions.explanation: The posterior forearm muscle group is made up of the wrist and finger extensors, as well as the supinators.

questions.question: What nerve innervates the flexor digitorum superficialis muscle?
questions.explanation: The flexor digitorum superficialis is innervated by the median nerve, which passes between its two portions.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles originates from the external supracondylar crest of the humerus and inserts into the external surface of the radius, above the styloid process?
questions.explanation: The Brachioradialis (Supinator longus) originates from the top of the external supracondylar crest of the humerus and inserts into the external aspect of the radius, just above the styloid process.

questions.question: What extensor muscle inserts on the dorsum of the base of the distal phalanx of the thumb?
questions.explanation: The Extensor pollicis longus inserts into the dorsum of the base of the distal phalanx of the thumb.

questions.question: At the elbow joint, what nerves control flexion?
questions.explanation: Flexion at the elbow joint is controlled by fibers that come from the C5 and C6 segments of the spinal cord.

questions.question: What nerve passes between the two portions of the Pronator teres muscle?
questions.explanation: The Pronator teres muscle is innervated by the median nerve, which generally passes between its two portions of origin.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles is an extensor and, along with the radials, acts to extend and adduct the hand?
questions.explanation: The posterior ulnar extends its hand and acts with the radials. Pure adduction occurs when this muscle acts with the ulnar anterior.

questions.question: The flexor digitorum profundus muscle divides into four tendons for the last four fingers. Where does each tendon insert?
options: On the dorsum of the base of the proximal phalanx
On the anterior surface of the base of the middle phalanx
On the posterior surface of the distal phalanx
On the anterior surface of the base of the distal phalanx
questions.explanation: Each tendon of the deep common flexor inserts into the anterior surface of the base of the distal phalanx, passing through the eyelet formed by the superficial tendon.

questions.question: The fascia of the forearm, also called the antebrachial aponeurosis, contributes to muscle attachments. Where is it inserted from behind?
options: At the styloid process of the radius
On the olecranon and the posterior border of the ulna
At the epicondyle of the humerus
At the coronoid process of the ulna
questions.explanation: The fascia of the forearm inserts posteriorly into the olecranon and into the posterior edge of the ulna.

questions.question: What structure is found in the 'floor' of the anatomical snuffbox, formed by the tendons of the Abductor longus and Extensor pollicis brevis?
questions.explanation: The radial artery is located on the floor of the anatomical snuffbox, which is made up of the scaphoid and trapezius bones.

questions.question: The term 'supination' refers to a position of the forearm where the palm of the hand faces forward. What is the main supinator muscle of the forearm?
questions.explanation: The supinator brevis is the main supinator of the forearm. The biceps brachii also helps in supination, especially in rapid movements or against resistance.

questions.question: Which nerve passes beneath the anterior annular ligament of the carpus and gives a recurrent branch to the muscles of the thenar eminence?
questions.explanation: The median nerve passes beneath the anterior annular ligament of the carpus (through the carpal tunnel) and, upon exiting, gives off a crucial recurrent branch to the muscles of the thenar eminence.

questions.question: What type of fibrous band is the anterior annular carpal ligament?
questions.explanation: The anterior annular carpal ligament is a strong transverse fibrous band that holds the flexor tendons and median nerve in the carpal canal.

questions.question: What are the three nerves that innervate the hand?
options: Radial nerve, ulnar nerve and axillary nerve
Median nerve, ulnar nerve and radial nerve
Musculocutaneous nerve, median nerve and ulnar nerve
Ulnar nerve, radial nerve and brachial nerve
questions.explanation: The hand is innervated by the median, ulnar and radial nerves. Each of these nerves has a specific innervation territory in the hand.

questions.question: What is the main function of the lumbrical muscles of the hand?
questions.explanation: The lumbricals are mainly extensors of the interphalangeal joints, and weak flexors of the metacarpophalangeal joints.

questions.question: What type of synovial sheaths surround the flexor tendons of the hand?
questions.explanation: The flexor tendons are wrapped by synovial sheaths that facilitate their sliding. The common sheath and flexor pollicis longus sheath are often called serous bursae.

questions.question: What is the muscle that lies deep in the palm and originates through two portions?
questions.explanation: The adductor pollicis is located deep in the palm and has two portions of origin: an oblique portion and a transverse portion.

questions.question: What condition can be caused by thickening and shortening of the palmar aponeurosis?
questions.explanation: The flexion deformity of one or more fingers, known as Dupuytren's contracture, is frequently attributed to thickening and shortening of the palmar aponeurosis.

questions.question: Where are the interosseous muscles located?
questions.explanation: The interosseous muscles are located partly between the metacarpal bones, and are divided into two groups: palmar and dorsal.

questions.question: What nerve supplies the muscles of the thenar eminence, such as the abductor brevis and flexor pollicis brevis?
questions.explanation: The muscles of the thenar eminence (abductor brevis, flexor pollicis and opponens pollicis) are generally innervated by the median nerve, through a special recurrent branch.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an intrinsic muscle of the hand?
questions.explanation: The intrinsic muscles of the hand are those of the thumb, those of the little finger, the palmar and dorsal interossei, and the lumbricals. The flexor digitorum digitorum is not an intrinsic muscle.

questions.question: What structures are found in the central compartment of the palm?
options: The flexor tendons, synovial sheaths, and lumbrical muscles
The carpal bones and ulnar nerve
The digital arteries and veins, and the interosseous fascia
questions.explanation: The central compartment of the palm contains the flexor tendons and their synovial sheaths, the lumbrical muscles, and the digital vessels and nerves.

questions.question: What nerve innervates the adductor pollicis?
questions.explanation: The adductor pollicis is innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, although it is rarely innervated by the median nerve.

questions.question: What is the function of the pinky opponent?
options: Bring the fifth metacarpal forward to deepen the concavity of the palm
questions.explanation: The opponent of the little finger brings the fifth metacarpal forward, helping to deepen the concavity of the palm.

questions.question: Which of the following ligaments is known to form a tunnel for the palmaris major tendon?
options: Superficial transverse ligament of the metacarpus
questions.explanation: The fibers of the anterior annular ligament of the carpus pass over the trapezius canal forming a tunnel for the palmaris major tendon.

questions.question: What is the function of the dorsal interosseous muscles?
questions.explanation: The dorsal interosseous muscles separate the fingers from a line that passes through the middle finger, a movement known as abduction.

questions.question: What nerve is responsible for carpal tunnel syndrome?
questions.explanation: Narrowing of the carpal canal can cause compression of the median nerve, causing carpal tunnel syndrome, with pain and numbness in certain fingers.

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of the skin of the palm of the hand?
questions.explanation: The skin of the palm is thicker and hairless, and is firmly attached to the underlying subcutaneous tissue by thick fibrous trabeculae.

questions.question: What structures make up fingerprints?
questions.explanation: Papillary ridges form a characteristic pattern on the palmar surface of the hand, especially on the pads of the fingers, where fingerprints develop.

questions.question: What type of infection affects the pad of a finger and causes stitches?
questions.explanation: Whitlow is a common infection of the ball of the finger, where fibrous septa prevent expansion, causing stabbing pain.

questions.question: What muscles of the hand act together to stabilize the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb during extension?
options: The adductor and flexor pollicis brevis
Flexor pollicis longus and abductor brevis
questions.explanation: During thumb extension, the opponens and abductor brevis act together to stabilize the joint.

questions.question: What is the function of the palmar cutaneous muscle?
options: Protect the ulnar artery and nerve from pressure
questions.explanation: The palmar cutaneous helps to increase the concavity of the palm and protects the ulnar artery and nerve from pressure on that region.

questions.question: What is the function of the opponens pollicis muscle?
options: Flex the thumb and rotate it medially
questions.explanation: The opponens pollicis muscle performs the opposition movement, which combines flexion and medial rotation of the first metacarpal, allowing the thumb to oppose the other fingers.

questions.question: What is the main nerve that innervates the muscles of the hand?
options: The median nerve and the ulnar nerve
questions.explanation: Hand movements are produced by muscles innervated by the median and ulnar nerves, although the radial nerve has a role in extension of the wrist and fingers.

questions.question: What pair of nerves innervate the lumbrical muscles of the hand?
questions.explanation: The two lateral lumbrical muscles are innervated by the median nerve, while the two medial lumbrical muscles are innervated by the ulnar nerve.

questions.question: What structure of the hand is paralyzed in a 'claw hand' caused by injury to the eighth cervical nerve and the first dorsal nerve?
options: The short muscles of the hand
questions.explanation: Lesions known as 'inferior type' (Dejerine-Klumpke) affect the lower cervical nerves and the first dorsal nerve, causing paralysis of the short muscles of the hand and a deformity known as 'claw hand'.

questions.question: Which movement of the thumb is primarily facilitated by the abductor pollicis brevis?
questions.explanation: The abductor pollicis brevis is one of the main muscles that performs abduction, separating the thumb from the palm.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles is a little finger abductor?
options: The abductor of the little finger
questions.explanation: The abductor little finger is one of the muscles of the hypothenar eminence whose main function is the abduction of the little finger.

questions.question: What movement occurs primarily at the radiocarpal joint of the wrist?
questions.explanation: Wrist adduction, also known as ulnar deviation, occurs predominantly at the radiocarpal joint.

questions.question: What nerve innervates the adductor pollicis muscle?
questions.explanation: The adductor pollicis, along with other intrinsic muscles of the hand, is innervated by the ulnar nerve.

questions.question: What muscle is a flexor pollicis and is part of the thenar eminence?
questions.explanation: The flexor pollicis brevis is located in the thenar eminence and is responsible for flexion of the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

questions.question: What is the function of the flexor digitorum brevis muscle?
options: Flex the little finger at its metacarpophalangeal joint
questions.explanation: The flexor digitorum brevis is a muscle of the hypothenar eminence that flexes the proximal phalanx of the little finger.

questions.question: Which of the following is an intrinsic muscle of the hand, responsible for flexion of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints?
questions.explanation: The lumbricals, although intrinsic to the hand, flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints. The other muscles mentioned are extrinsic.

questions.question: What type of nerves predominate in the innervation of the skin of the hand?
questions.explanation: The skin of the hand is rich in sensory nerves, since the hand is a very sensitive organ of touch and perception.

questions.question: Where are the palmar interosseous muscles located?
options: On the back of the hand
In the deepest plane of the palm, between the metacarpals
questions.explanation: The palmar interossei, as their name indicates, are located in the palm, specifically between the metacarpal bones, and their main function is the adduction of the fingers.

questions.question: What is the main function of the dorsal interosseous muscles?
questions.explanation: The dorsal interossei are responsible for abducting or separating the fingers, moving them away from the central axis of the hand.

questions.question: What nerve innervates the flexor digitorum brevis muscle?
questions.explanation: The flexor digitorum brevis, like the other muscles of the hypothenar eminence, is innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

questions.question: What type of joint is the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb?
questions.explanation: The carpometacarpal joint of the thumb is a saddle joint, allowing it a wide variety of movements, including opposition.

questions.question: What tendon is found on the radial aspect of the wrist?
questions.explanation: The flexor pollicis longus tendon is located in a separate compartment of the anterior annular carpal ligament, on the radial side of the wrist.

questions.question: Which muscle is most important for the opposition movement of the thumb?
questions.explanation: The opponens pollicis is the muscle that is responsible for medial rotation and flexion of the thumb, essential for opposition movement against the other fingers.

questions.question: Which hand deformity is associated with an 'inferior type' (Dejerine-Klumpke) nerve injury?
questions.explanation: Injury to the nerves in the lower part of the brachial plexus (C8 and D1) can lead to paralysis of the intrinsic hand muscles, resulting in a 'claw hand'.

questions.question: What is the main function of the palmar interosseous muscles?
questions.explanation: The palmar interossei are responsible for adducting the fingers, that is, bringing them together and moving them towards the midline of the central finger.

questions.question: What are the three bones that fuse in adults to form the coxal bone?
questions.explanation: The coxal bone is formed by the fusion of the ilium, ischium and pubis in the region of the acetabulum in adult life.

questions.question: What is the name of the widened upper extremity of the ilium that can be palpated along its entire length?
questions.explanation: The iliac crest is the widened upper extremity of the ilium bone, which is a palpable anatomical reference.

questions.question: What important landmark on the abdominal wall can be palpated following the inguinal ligament upward?
questions.explanation: The anterior superior iliac spine is an important landmark that can be found by palpating along the inguinal ligament.

questions.question: What part of the ischium does the body weight rest on when a person is sitting?
options: The ascending ramus of the ischium
questions.explanation: The ischial tuberosity is the part of the ischium bone that supports the weight of the body when sitting.

questions.question: Which bone in the body is the longest and heaviest?
questions.explanation: The femur, or thigh bone, is recognized as the longest and heaviest bone in the human skeleton.

questions.question: What is the name of the large cup-shaped cavity on the external surface of the coxal bone that articulates with the head of the femur?
questions.explanation: The acetabulum is the cavity in the hip bone where the head of the femur fits to form the hip joint.

questions.question: In which part of the femur are the head, neck, and two trochanters (greater and lesser) located?
questions.explanation: The superior epiphysis of the femur is the portion that includes the head, neck, and the two trochanters, greater and lesser.

questions.question: What name is given to the condition in which the angle of inclination of the neck of the femur increases?
questions.explanation: Coxa valga is the term used to describe a condition in which the angle of inclination of the neck of the femur is greater than normal.

questions.question: What is the depression or fossa in the head of the femur where the round ligament inserts?
options: The fossa for the round ligament
questions.explanation: The ligament of the head of the femur inserts into a specific depression, known as the round ligament fossa, located on the head of the femur.

questions.question: What line extends on the anterior surface of the femur, separating the neck from the shaft?
questions.explanation: The intertrochanteric line is a ridge that marks the separation between the neck and the shaft of the femur on its anterior surface.

questions.question: What type of Y-shaped cartilage separates the three primary centers of the hip bone in the acetabulum in late infancy?
questions.explanation: The triradiate cartilage, which has a Y shape, is what keeps the ossification centers of the ilium, ischium and pubis separated in the acetabulum before their fusion.

questions.question: What is the rugose eminence on the ilium that is located slightly above the acetabulum?
questions.explanation: The anterior inferior iliac spine is a rough protuberance located just above the acetabulum on the ilium bone.

questions.question: What structure joins the pubic body in the midline to form the pubic symphysis?
options: The horizontal ramus of the pubis
The ascending ramus of the ischium
questions.explanation: The body of the pubis joins with the body of the pubis on the opposite side in the midline of the body, forming the joint known as the symphysis pubis.

questions.question: What is the name of the cavity of the acetabulum that is smooth and articulates with the head of the femur?
questions.explanation: Within the acetabulum, the semilunar surface is the smooth portion that is the main area of ​​contact and articulation with the head of the femur.

questions.question: What bone in the body is used to calculate height due to its length?
questions.explanation: The length of the femur is directly related to a person's height, making it a key bone in estimating height.

questions.question: What is the name of the oblique groove on the obturator surface of the horizontal ramus of the pubis that houses the obturator nerve and vessels?
questions.explanation: The subpubic canal, or obturator sulcus, is the structure of the pubis that allows the passage of the obturator vessels and nerves.

questions.question: What ligament inserts into the anterior superior iliac spine?
questions.explanation: The anterior superior iliac spine is the insertion point for the inguinal ligament.

questions.question: What is the term for the state in which the angle of inclination of the neck of the femur decreases?
questions.explanation: Coxa vara is the condition in which the angle formed between the neck and the shaft of the femur is less than normal.

questions.question: What structures form the obturated foramen?
options: The pubis and ischium and their branches
questions.explanation: The foramen obturata is a large opening in the pelvis that is surrounded by the pubic and ischium bones and their respective branches.

questions.question: What is the joint between the hip bone and the sacrum called?
questions.explanation: The hip bone articulates with the sacrum from behind to form the sacroiliac joint.

questions.question: What triangular-shaped sesamoid bone is included in the tendon of the quadriceps femoris muscle?
questions.explanation: The kneecap, also known as the patella, is a triangular-shaped sesamoid bone that is located in the front of the knee and is integrated into the quadriceps femoris tendon.

questions.question: What part of the tibia is the most common site for open fractures, for example in motorcycle accidents?
questions.explanation: The shaft of the tibia, which is the middle portion of the bone, is especially vulnerable and prone to open fractures due to its subcutaneous position in the front of the leg.

questions.question: At what stage of life does the center for the head of the femur ossify?
questions.explanation: The ossification center for the head of the femur appears during the first years of life or the breastfeeding period, unlike the center of the distal epiphysis that is usually present at birth.

questions.question: Which bone in the body, after the femur, is the longest and heaviest?
questions.explanation: The tibia is the second longest and heaviest bone in the human body, after the femur, and is located in the front and inner part of the leg.

questions.question: What structure divides the articular surface of the patella into a larger outer facet and a smaller inner facet?
questions.explanation: A vertical, rounded ridge on the posterior or articular surface of the patella is responsible for separating the two articular facets that adapt to the femoral trochlea.

questions.question: What important landmark of the leg can be palpated along its entire length and is popularly known as the 'shin'?
options: The anterior edge of the tibia
The interosseous border of the fibula
questions.explanation: The anterior edge or crest of the tibia is the most prominent of the edges of the bone and, being subcutaneous, is easily palpable throughout its entire length, which is why it is commonly called 'the shinbone'.

questions.question: What name is given to the vertex or upward extension of the head of the fibula?
questions.explanation: The apex of the upper epiphysis of the fibula is known as the styloid process and projects upward from the head of the bone.

questions.question: What main artery reaches the head of the femur through the round ligament?
questions.explanation: The internal epiphyseal branches, which originate from the obturator artery, are those that reach the head of the femur through the round ligament for irrigation.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the kneecap?
options: It articulates in front with the trochlea of ​​the femur.
Supports a large part of the body weight.
The external articular facet is larger than the internal one.
questions.explanation: The articular surface of the patella is divided by a ridge, resulting in a wider external articular facet and a smaller internal one, with the external one determining the side of the bone.

questions.question: What ligament inserts into the upper edge of the kneecap?
questions.explanation: The tendon of the quadriceps femoris muscle is the main structure that inserts into the upper edge, or base, of the kneecap.

questions.question: What is the name of the large nutritional opening that is usually found in the upper third of the posterior surface of the shaft of the tibia?
questions.explanation: The nutritive foramen, where blood vessels enter to supply the bone, is commonly found on the upper part of the posterior aspect of the shaft of the tibia.

questions.question: What nerve surrounds the fibula behind the head, and can be palpated on the outside of the neck?
questions.explanation: The lateral popliteal sciatic nerve, also known as the common peroneal nerve, passes behind the head of the fibula and can be rolled by palpation at the neck of the bone.

questions.question: What is the main function of the tibia in the standing position?
options: Transmit the weight of the femur to the bones of the foot
questions.explanation: The tibia is the main weight-bearing bone of the leg, transmitting the load from the femur to the ankle and foot, unlike the non-weight-bearing fibula.

questions.question: What structures form the intercondylar eminence at the superior epiphysis of the tibia?
options: The anterior and posterior intercondylar areas
The internal and external intercondylar tubercles
questions.explanation: The intercondylar eminence, which is located between the condyles, is formed by the prolongation of the internal and external intercondylar tubercles.

questions.question: Which of the following structures does not articulate with the fibula?
questions.explanation: The fibula articulates with the tibia above and with the talus below, in addition to joining the tibia by the interosseous membrane, but it has no direct articulation with the femur.

questions.question: What part of the tibia is tilted slightly posteriorly and consists of two condyles?
questions.explanation: The upper epiphysis of the tibia is the voluminous portion that is expanded to articulate with the femur and is slightly inclined posteriorly.

questions.question: What part of the inferior epiphysis of the tibia is lodged in the peroneal notch?
options: The lower portion of the fibula
questions.explanation: The external surface of the lower epiphysis of the tibia has a deep depression, the peroneal notch, which is designed to receive the lower part of the fibula.

questions.question: What is the name of the ridge on the posterior surface of the fibula that subdivides it?
questions.explanation: The posterior surface of the fibula is subdivided by a prominent internal ridge.

questions.question: What structure is related to the non-articular portion of the posterior aspect of the patella?
questions.explanation: The posterior aspect of the patella has a non-articular portion that lies in relation to the infrapatellar fat pad.

questions.question: What is the smooth triangular facet on the lower end of the fibula that faces inward?
options: The articular surface for the tibia
The articular surface for the talus
questions.explanation: On the lower epiphysis of the fibula (lateral malleolus), the smooth, inward-facing triangular facet is the articular surface for the talus.

questions.question: What is the tarsal bone that articulates with the calcaneus behind and the three cuneiforms in front?
questions.explanation: The scaphoid bone, also known as the navicular, is located between the talus at the back and the three cuneiform bones at the front of the foot.

questions.question: What is the name of the tubercle that can be palpated about 3 cm below and in front of the medial malleolus?
