questions.explanation: The scaphoid tuberosity is a bony projection on the inner surface of the foot that is easily palpable.

questions.question: Which tarsal bone has a saddle-shaped articular facet for the calcaneus on its posterior surface?
questions.explanation: The cuboid bone, located on the external surface of the foot, articulates with the calcaneus through a saddle-shaped articular facet on its posterior surface.

questions.question: Which groove on the inferior aspect of the cuboid bone is often occupied by the peroneus longus tendon?
options: The groove for the flexor of the big toe
questions.explanation: The inferior surface of the cuboid has an oblique groove forward and inward that serves as a passage for the tendon of the peroneus longus muscle.

questions.question: Which metatarsal bone is the longest?
questions.explanation: The second metatarsal is the longest bone of the five metatarsals.

questions.question: What is the distinguishing feature of the base of the fifth metatarsal?
options: It is the widest of all
It has a styloid process that projects backwards and outwards.
It articulates with the internal and external cuneiform
questions.explanation: The base of the fifth metatarsal is characterized by a bony projection called the styloid process, which is an important landmark.

questions.question: How many phalanges does each toe have, except the first?
questions.explanation: Each toe, with the exception of the big toe, has three phalanges: proximal, middle, and distal.

questions.question: Which sesamoid bone is commonly found in the peroneus longus tendon?
questions.explanation: Some sesamoid bones are included in tendons, such as the peroneal sesamoid found in the peroneus longus tendon.

questions.question: What digital veins join to form the dorsal metatarsal veins?
options: The deep veins of the leg
questions.explanation: The dorsal digital veins, which run along the back of the toes, join at the level of the interdigital folds to form the dorsal veins of the metatarsus.

questions.question: What is the name of the superficial vein that begins at the junction of the dorsal digital vein on the inner side of the big toe with the dorsal venous arch?
questions.explanation: The internal saphenous vein, or great vein, is a large-caliber superficial vein that originates on the dorsum of the foot at the junction of the dorsal digital vein of the big toe with the dorsal venous arch.

questions.question: What type of vein is characterized by having permanently lost its valvular efficiency?
questions.explanation: A varicose vein is one that, due to the loss of efficiency of its valves, becomes dilated and tortuous, preventing the correct return of blood to the heart.

questions.question: Which vein pierces the fascia of the popliteal fossa and often terminates in the popliteal or internal saphenous vein?
questions.explanation: The external saphenous vein ascends the posterior surface of the leg, crosses the fascia of the popliteal fossa and empties variably, commonly into the popliteal vein.

questions.question: Through which veins does most of the blood from the lower limb return?
questions.explanation: Most of the venous return of the lower limb occurs through the deep veins, which receive blood from the superficial veins through the perforator veins.

questions.question: What are the names of the veins that connect the superficial veins with the deep ones?
questions.explanation: Perforating veins, also known as communicating veins, are conduits that join the superficial veins with the deep venous system, allowing blood flow between the two.

questions.question: In which direction does blood flow in the perforator veins above the ankle?
questions.explanation: Above the ankle, the valves of the perforator veins are oriented to direct blood flow from the superficial veins to the deep veins.

questions.question: Which tarsal bone can be palpated on the outside of the foot?
questions.explanation: The cuboid bone, one of the structures of the tarsus, is located on the external surface of the foot and is a palpable anatomical point.

questions.question: What type of bone is the kneecap?
questions.explanation: The kneecap, also known as the patella, is a triangular-shaped sesamoid bone found within the quadriceps tendon.

questions.question: Which structure of the tibia is the most common site for open fractures?
questions.explanation: La diáfisis de la tibia es la porción media y es la más propensa a fracturas abiertas debido a su posición subcutánea.

questions.question: What is the name of the process that projects backwards and outwards on the lateral side of the base of the fifth metatarsal?
questions.explanation: The styloid process is a characteristic prominence at the base of the fifth metatarsal, which projects backwards and outwards.

questions.question: What nerve passes behind the head of the fibula and can be palpated on the outside of the neck?
questions.explanation: The external popliteal sciatic nerve, also known as the common peroneal nerve, has a superficial course behind the head of the fibula, making it palpable in that area.

questions.question: What is the nerve considered the largest in the body?
questions.explanation: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body, it consists of two joined nerves: the internal popliteal sciatic (tibial) and the external popliteal sciatic (common peroneal).

questions.question: What muscles are found in the posterior thigh region?
questions.explanation: The muscles of the posterior region of the thigh are the biceps femoris, the semitendinosus and the semimembranosus.

questions.question: What is the main action of the adductor muscle group?
options: Internal rotation and flexion of the hip
questions.explanation: The main action of the adductor muscles, including the pectineus, is adduction of the thigh.

questions.question: What is the main flexor of the thigh and trunk?
questions.explanation: The iliopsoas, composed of the iliacus and psoas major, is the main flexor of the thigh and trunk.

questions.question: What nerve innervates the quadriceps femoris?
questions.explanation: The quadriceps femoris, located in the anterior region of the thigh, is innervated by the femoral nerve.

questions.question: Injury to the sciatic nerve can lead to a condition known as:
questions.explanation: A complete cut of the sciatic nerve hinders dorsiflexion at the ankle and eversion of the foot, causing the foot to hang in an equinovarus position, known as foot drop.

questions.question: What is the fascia of the thigh known?
questions.explanation: The fascia that surrounds the muscles of the thigh is known as fascia lata.

questions.question: What is one of the external limits of the femoral triangle?
questions.explanation: The femoral triangle is limited outwardly by the inner border of the sartorius muscle.

questions.question: What structures are located within the adductor canal?
options: The femoral vessels and the internal saphenous nerve
The sciatic nerve and gluteal artery
The great saphenous vein and iliac artery
The femoral nerve and the external saphenous vein
questions.explanation: The adductor canal, also called subsartorial, contains the femoral vessels, the internal saphenous nerve, and usually the vastus medialis nerve.

questions.question: What are the two fasciae that make up the femoral sheath?
options: The transversalis fascia and the fascia lata
The subsartorial fascia and the iliac fascia
questions.explanation: The femoral sheath is formed by an extension of the transversalis fascia in front and the iliaca fascia behind.

questions.question: What nerve innervates the gluteus maximus muscle?
questions.explanation: The inferior gluteal nerve passes through the greater sacrosciatic foramen and divides to supply the gluteus maximus muscle.

questions.question: Which branch of the sciatic nerve innervates the short head of the biceps femoris?
questions.explanation: The short head of the biceps femoris is innervated by the external or peroneal component of the sciatic nerve.

questions.question: Injury to the superior gluteal nerve is mainly manifested by:
options: Loss of sensation in the thigh
Weakening of thigh flexion and internal rotation
questions.explanation: Injury to the superior gluteal nerve is characterized by sagging of the gluteus medius, which weakens thigh flexion and inward rotation.

questions.question: What muscles help the posterior thigh muscles in thigh extension?
options: A portion of the adductor magnus
questions.explanation: A portion of the adductor magnus helps the posterior thigh muscles extend the thigh.

questions.question: Which muscles of the posterior thigh act as leg flexors and thigh extensors?
questions.explanation: The posterior thigh muscles, also known as the hamstring muscles (biceps femoris, semitendinosus, semimembranosus), are the main thigh extensors and leg flexors.

questions.question: What is the ellipsoidal cleft in the fascia lata that gives way to the internal saphenous vein known?
options: The opening of the saphenous vein (fossa ovale)
questions.explanation: The fossa ovale is a slit in the fascia lata, about 4 cm below and outside the pubic spine, which allows the passage of the internal saphenous vein into the femoral vein.

questions.question: The extensor portion of the adductor magnus is a branch of which nerve?
questions.explanation: The extensor portion of the adductor magnus is innervated by the medial or tibial component of the sciatic nerve.

questions.question: What happens to the gait of a patient with a complete cut of the sciatic nerve?
options: It is peculiar, since hip flexion is increased to separate the hanging foot from the ground
Swings inward due to abductor paralysis
It is impossible due to total paralysis of the lower limb
questions.explanation: A patient with a complete cut of the sciatic nerve can stand, but his gait is peculiar because flexion at the hip is increased to compensate for the 'drop foot'.

questions.question: What nerve innervates the muscles of the adductor region of the thigh?
questions.explanation: Most of the muscles of the adductor region of the thigh, including the pectineus, adductor medius, and adductor minor, are innervated by the obturator nerve.

questions.question: Where does the long head of the biceps femoris muscle originate from?
options: At the head of the fibula
questions.explanation: The long head of the biceps femoris muscle originates from the medial facet of the ischial tuberosity, along with the semitendinosus.

questions.question: What veins are formed in the knee by the union of the satellite veins of the anterior and posterior tibial arteries?
questions.explanation: There are two popliteal veins and they are formed in the knee by the union of the satellite veins of the anterior and posterior tibial arteries. They end up becoming the femoral veins as they pass through the ring of the third adductor.

questions.question: Which of the following nerves is more exposed to injury than any other branch of the sciatic nerve?
questions.explanation: The external popliteal or common peroneal sciatic nerve is the branch of the sciatic nerve that is most exposed to injury due to its location.

questions.question: What condition can result from injury to the external popliteal sciatic nerve?
questions.explanation: Injury to the external popliteal sciatic nerve can cause loss of dorsiflexion and eversion, resulting in the condition known as foot drop.

questions.question: What muscles are innervated by the muscular branches of the internal popliteal sciatic nerve?
questions.explanation: The muscular branches of the internal popliteal sciatic nerve supply the gastrocnemius muscles of the leg, soleus, plantaris thin, popliteus and tibialis posterior.

questions.question: What type of joint is the hip?
questions.explanation: The hip joint is a very resistant and stable enarthrosis, formed by the head of the femur and the acetabulum of the coxal bone.

questions.question: What is the strongest and most important ligament in the hip joint?
questions.explanation: The iliofemoral ligament is the strongest and most important ligament of the hip joint. It is a 'Y' shaped fibrous band that allows backward leaning when standing.

questions.question: By what nerves is the hip joint innervated?
options: Crural nerves, obturator, superior gluteus and quadratus cruris
Obturator nerve and inferior gluteal nerve
questions.explanation: The hip joint is innervated by the femoral, obturator, and superior gluteal nerves, as well as by the quadratus femoris nerve and sometimes the accessory obturator.

questions.question: What movement of the thigh is carried out around a horizontal axis that passes through the head of the femur?
questions.explanation: Flexion and extension of the thigh at the hip joint are carried out around a horizontal axis that passes through the head of the femur.

questions.question: What is the strongest thigh flexor?
questions.explanation: The iliopsoas is the most powerful of the thigh flexors.

questions.question: What muscles abduct the thigh?
questions.explanation: The gluteus medius and minimus are the main muscles that abduct the thigh.

questions.question: What condition occurs when the angle between the long axes of the femur and tibia is more pronounced, causing the knees to collide with each other?
questions.explanation: When the angle between the axes of the femur and tibia is more pronounced, a condition called genu valgus occurs, in which the knees collide with each other.

questions.question: What structure serves as a capsule on the anterior surface of the knee?
questions.explanation: On the anterior surface of the knee joint, the patella and the patellar ligament serve as the capsule.

questions.question: What are the sheets of fascia and aponeurosis that reinforce the knee capsule on both sides known?
options: Internal and external fins of the patella
questions.explanation: The sheets of fascia and aponeurosis that reinforce the capsule on either side of the knee are known as the inner and outer fins of the patella.

questions.question: Which serous bursa of the knee can become inflamed to produce the so-called 'maid's knee'?
questions.explanation: The prepatellar subcutaneous serous bursa, which is located between the skin and the bottom of the kneecap, can become inflamed and cause 'maid's knee'.

questions.question: Which ligament of the knee is a wide, flattened fibrous band that extends from the medial epicondyle of the femur to the medial aspect of the tibia?
questions.explanation: The medial collateral (tibial) ligament is a wide, flattened fibrous band that extends from the medial epicondyle of the femur to the medial aspect of the tibia.

questions.question: Which of the knee menisci is 'C' shaped and torn most often?
questions.explanation: The medial meniscus is 'C' shaped, attached to the medial collateral ligament and is torn much more frequently in flexed knee sprain injuries.

questions.question: What nerves innervate the knee joint?
options: Crural nerve, internal saphenous nerve, and internal and external popliteal sciatic nerves
questions.explanation: The knee joint is innervated by fibers from the muscular branches of the crural nerve, the internal saphenous nerve, and branches of the internal popliteal sciatic, external popliteal sciatic, and obturator nerves.

questions.question: What structure of the hip joint increases the depth of the acetabulum?
questions.explanation: The acetabulum labrum is a fibrous structure that borders the acetabulum, increasing its depth.

questions.question: Which hip ligament is a flattened or prismatic triangular band that inserts into the fossa of the head of the femur?
questions.explanation: The round ligament (ligament of the head of the femur) is a flattened or triangular band that inserts into the socket of the head of the femur.

questions.question: What structure separates the external collateral ligament of the knee from the external meniscus?
questions.explanation: The tendon of the popliteus muscle is separated from the lateral meniscus by the external collateral ligament.

questions.question: What artery is continuous with the anterior tibial artery on the dorsum of the foot?
questions.explanation: The anterior tibial artery often has a well-defined direct continuation on the dorsum of the foot, known as the pedis artery.

questions.question: Which nerve is one of the terminal branches of the external popliteal sciatic nerve?
questions.explanation: The anterior tibial nerve, also known as the deep peroneal nerve, is one of the terminal branches of the external popliteal sciatic nerve.

questions.question: What condition results from paralysis of the foot dorsiflexors and toe extensors due to an injury to the anterior tibial nerve?
questions.explanation: Injury to the anterior tibial nerve paralyzes the foot dorsiflexors and toe extensors, causing drop foot and steppe gait.

questions.question: What muscles of the external region of the leg are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve?
options: Tibialis posterior and flexor digitorum longus
questions.explanation: The two muscles of the outer region of the leg, the peroneus longus and brevis, are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve.

questions.question: What does the tendon of the peroneus longus muscle insert into after crossing the sole of the foot?
options: External surface of the first cuneiform and the base of the first metatarsal
questions.explanation: The peroneus longus tendon crosses the sole of the foot to insert into the external surface of the first cuneiform and the same surface as the base of the first metatarsal.

questions.question: What main action does the peroneus longus muscle perform?
options: Plantar flexion and eversion of the foot
questions.explanation: The peroneus longus produces plantar flexion and eversion of the foot.

questions.question: What muscles make up the triceps surae?
options: Calves of the leg and soleus
Flexor digitorum digitorum and flexor hallucis longus
questions.explanation: The superficial muscles of the posterior region of the leg, the gastrocnemius of the leg and the soleus, form the triceps surae.

questions.question: What muscles of the posterior region of the leg are innervated by the internal popliteal sciatic nerve?
options: All muscles of the posterior region
Only the gastrocnemius and the soleus
Only the popliteus and flexor digitorum longus
Tibialis posterior and flexor hallucis longus
questions.explanation: All muscles of the posterior region of the leg, both superficial and deep, are innervated by the internal popliteal sciatic nerve.

questions.question: What is the name of the sesamoid bone that is sometimes found in the lateral gastrocnemius?
questions.explanation: The lateral twin may contain a sesamoid bone known as the fabella.

questions.question: What main action does the popliteus muscle perform?
questions.explanation: The main action of the popliteus muscle is the inward rotation of the tibia.

questions.question: Which structure of the knee is pulled back by the popliteus muscle when flexion begins?
questions.explanation: The popliteus muscle pulls the lateral meniscus backward as the knee begins to flexion.

questions.question: What muscle is considered the key to understanding the leg?
questions.explanation: The tibialis posterior, due to its extensive origin and deep position, is considered the key to understanding the leg.

questions.question: What is the main inverter muscle of the foot?
questions.explanation: The tibialis posterior is the main inverter muscle of the foot.

questions.question: What structure contains a fibrocartilage or a sesamoid bone in its course behind the medial malleolus?
questions.explanation: The tibialis posterior tendon contains a fibrocartilage or sesamoid bone in its course, immediately below the plantar calcaneoscaphoid ligament.

questions.question: Which artery arises below the inferior border of the popliteus and runs more or less parallel to the posterior tibial artery?
questions.explanation: The peroneal artery usually has the same caliber as the posterior tibial artery and follows a course more or less parallel to it.

questions.question: What nerves innervate the nail beds and balls of the toes?
options: Anterior tibial nerve and musculocutaneous nerve
questions.explanation: The nail beds and pads of the fingers are innervated by the plantar digital branches of the medial and lateral plantar nerves.

questions.question: What tibial vessels pass through an arch in the interosseous membrane?
questions.explanation: The anterior tibial vessels reach the anterior compartment of the leg through an arch located in the posterosuperior part of the interosseous membrane.

questions.question: What structures make up the internal annular ligament?
questions.explanation: The internal annular ligament extends between the medial malleolus and the inner surface of the calcaneus.

questions.question: What happens if the internal popliteal sciatic nerve is injured in the popliteal fossa?
options: Only the intrinsic muscles of the foot are paralyzed
Loss of sensation in the back of the foot
All the muscles of the calf and the intrinsic muscles of the foot are paralyzed.
Pendulum foot and steppe-type gait occur
questions.explanation: If an injury to the internal popliteal sciatic nerve occurs in the popliteal fossa, all the muscles of the calf and the intrinsic muscles of the foot are paralyzed.

questions.question: What is the nutrient artery of the tibia?
options: A branch of the peroneal artery
A branch of the posterior tibial artery
A branch of the popliteal artery
A branch of the anterior tibial artery
questions.explanation: The nutrient artery for the tibia is a branch of the posterior tibial artery and is the largest of the nutrient arteries for the long bones.

questions.question: What artery is located between the tendon of the extensor hallucis longus and the tendons of the extensor digitorum communis?
questions.explanation: The pedis artery, which is the continuation of the anterior tibial artery, is of great clinical importance and its pulsations can be felt between the tendon of the extensor hallucis longus and those of the extensor digitorum communis.

questions.question: What type of reflex is produced when the sole of an infant's foot is stimulated and the big toe is slowly extended with a slight separation from the other toes?
questions.explanation: The Babinski reflex is the response observed in infants and in patients with certain motor pathway disorders, where stimulation of the sole of the foot causes slow extension of the big toe and separation of the other toes.

questions.question: Which of the two terminal branches of the posterior tibial artery is generally the thinnest?
questions.explanation: The internal plantar artery is generally the thinner of the two terminal branches of the posterior tibial artery.

questions.question: Which nerve in the foot is comparable to the ulnar nerve in the upper limb?
questions.explanation: The external plantar nerve, which innervates several muscles and the skin on the outer side of the sole and toes, is comparable to the ulnar nerve of the upper limb.

questions.question: What structures form a mortise, wider in front than behind, within which the talus moves?
questions.explanation: The tibia and fibula form a mortise that articulates with the talus, allowing dorsiflexion and plantar flexion movements.

questions.question: Which ligament inserts above on the medial malleolus and below on the talus, scaphoid, and calcaneus?
questions.explanation: The medial ligament, also known as the deltoid ligament, is a thickening of the capsule on the medial side of the ankle and inserts into the medial malleolus, talus, scaphoid, and calcaneus.

questions.question: What type of joint is the ankle joint?
questions.explanation: The ankle joint is a trochlearthrosis joint, which allows dorsiflexion and plantarflexion.

questions.question: What ligament originates from the malleolar fossa of the fibula along with the transverse ligament?
questions.explanation: The posterior talofibular ligament is an independent fibrous band that originates from the malleolar fossa of the fibula along with the transverse ligament.

questions.question: In which joints are the main inversion and eversion movements of the foot carried out?
questions.explanation: Inversion and eversion of the foot occur primarily at the subtalar and transverse tarsal joints.

questions.question: What ligament is found between the Sustainaculum Tali and the scaphoid, completing the cavity of the talocalcaneoscaphoid joint?
questions.explanation: The plantar calcaneoscaphoid ligament joins the sustainculum tali with the scaphoid and completes the joint cavity, acting as the main support for the longitudinal arch of the foot.

questions.question: Which branch is the largest of the two terminal branches of the posterior tibial nerve?
questions.explanation: The medial plantar nerve is the larger of the two terminal branches of the posterior tibial nerve.

questions.question: What nerve innervates the flexor hallucis brevis and first lumbrical?
questions.explanation: The medial plantar nerve, through its terminal branches, innervates the flexor hallucis brevis and first lumbrical muscles.

questions.question: Which artery, of clinical importance, is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery?
questions.explanation: The pediatric artery, which is the continuation of the anterior tibial artery, is clinically important to assess peripheral circulation in the foot.

questions.question: What structures form the plantar venous arch?
options: The internal and external plantar veins
questions.explanation: The plantar interosseous veins join to form the plantar venous arch.

questions.question: What ligament prevents the investment from going over?
options: The ligament of the tarsal canal
questions.explanation: It has been claimed that the cervical ligament, which extends into the neck of the talus, limits inversion motion.

questions.question: What foot movement includes pronation, abduction, and dorsiflexion?
questions.explanation: Foot eversion is a complex movement that includes pronation, abduction, and dorsiflexion.

questions.question: Which ligament originates from most of the plantar aspect of the calcaneus and extends to the tuberosity of the cuboid?
questions.explanation: The long plantar ligament originates on the plantar aspect of the calcaneus and extends anteriorly to the tuberosity of the cuboid.

questions.question: Where are the fat pads and synovial folds of the ankle joint located?
options: In the anterior and posterior parts of the joint
In the sinus of the tarsus
questions.explanation: Fat pads and synovial folds are located in the anterior and posterior parts of the ankle joint.

questions.question: What is the function of the interosseous ligament of the tibiofibular syndesmosis?
options: Strengthen the capsule on the outer side of the ankle
Join the adjacent surfaces of the tibia and fibula and keep the malleoli pressed against the talus
questions.explanation: The interosseous ligament joins the adjacent surfaces of the tibia and fibula, helping to keep the malleolus firmly pressed against the talus.

questions.question: What joints allow a simple gliding movement in the foot?
questions.explanation: The tarsometatarsal and intermetatarsal joints are arthrodia that allow simple gliding, which together gives elasticity and torsion capacity to the front part of the foot.

questions.question: What is the main function of the hip abductors during walking?
options: Minimize pelvic tilt on the side of the free limb.
Stabilize the arches of the foot.
questions.explanation: The hip abductors contract strongly during the stance phase of walking to minimize pelvic tilt toward the free limb side, which contributes to stabilization.

questions.question: What important landmark is located following the iliac crest downwards or the inguinal ligament upwards?
options: The tubercle of the third adductor.
questions.explanation: The anterior superior iliac spine is a key landmark that can be located by following the iliac crest downward or the inguinal ligament upward.

questions.question: What structure is indicated by a line running from the posterior superior iliac spine to the ischial tuberosity?
questions.explanation: The sciatic nerve exits the pelvis at approximately the upper point of trisection of the line from the posterior superior iliac spine to the ischial tuberosity.

questions.question: What parts make up the thorax skeleton?
questions.explanation: The skeleton of the thorax is made up of the dorsal (thoracic) vertebrae, intervertebral discs, ribs, costal cartilages and the sternum.

questions.question: What is the bony reference point that indicates the union of the manubrium with the body of the sternum and the level of the second costal cartilage?
questions.explanation: The angle of Louis, or sternal angle, is a palpable reference point that indicates the junction of the manubrium with the body of the sternum and the level of the second costal cartilage.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the sternum is correct?
options: It can be punctured to aspirate bone marrow.
It is made up of two parts: handlebars and body.
It is a long and curved bone.
It is the thickest bone in the thorax.
questions.explanation: Due to its easy access and the thin thickness of its compact lamina, the sternum can be punctured with a needle to aspirate bone marrow and perform studies.

questions.question: How are the XI and XII ribs classified?
questions.explanation: The XI and XII ribs are called floating ribs because they are free, that is, they do not attach to the sternum or the upper costal cartilages.

questions.question: What structures join to form the costal margin?
questions.explanation: The seventh to tenth pair of costal cartilages join on each side and their inner edges form the costal margin.

questions.question: What type of bone is the sternum?
questions.explanation: The sternum, also known as the chest bone, is a flat bone that forms part of the bony wall of the chest.

questions.question: What is the approximate level of the spinous process of the L4 vertebra?
questions.explanation: The supracrestile plane, which joins the highest points of the iliac crests, is at the level of the spinous process of the L4 vertebra.

questions.question: Which nerve descends behind the middle part of the inguinal ligament, outside the femoral artery?
questions.explanation: The femoral nerve descends behind the middle part of the inguinal ligament, outside the femoral artery, and divides after a short course.

questions.question: What structure of the thorax houses the heart and lungs?
questions.explanation: The thoracic cavity is the space that houses vital organs such as the heart, lungs, and other important structures.

questions.question: What bone structure is palpable when the thigh is flexed?
options: The tubercle of the third adductor.
questions.explanation: The ischial tuberosity is a bony prominence that can be palpated when the thigh is in a flexed position.

questions.question: Which nerve is palpable against the biceps and fibula?
questions.explanation: The external popliteal sciatic nerve descends and surrounds the neck of the fibula, being palpable against the biceps and fibula.

questions.question: How is the shape of the thorax described in adults compared to that at birth?
options: It is narrower transversely than anteroposteriorly.
It is wider transversely than anteroposteriorly.
questions.explanation: At birth, the thorax is almost circular, but in the adult, it becomes wider transversely than anteroposteriorly.

questions.question: What is the widest and thickest part of the sternum?
questions.explanation: Of the three parts of the sternum, the manubrium is the widest and thickest.

questions.question: Which vein begins on the dorsum of the foot and ascends behind the external malleolus?
questions.explanation: The external saphenous vein begins on the dorsum of the foot, passes behind the external malleolus and ascends to the popliteal fossa.

questions.question: What structure is located following the tibialis anterior tendon forward in the dorsiflexed foot?
options: The styloid process of the fifth metatarsal.
questions.explanation: The first cuneiform is located following the tibialis anterior tendon forward in the foot when it is in dorsiflexion.

questions.question: Which artery can be felt pulsing when the thigh is flexed, abducted, and externally rotated?
questions.explanation: Pulsations of the femoral artery can be felt when the thigh is flexed, abducted, and externally rotated.

questions.question: What is the function of the thoracic skeleton?
options: Enclose and protect the heart and lungs.
Support the arches of the foot.
questions.explanation: The skeleton of the thorax, made up of vertebrae, ribs and sternum, has the main function of enclosing and protecting vital organs such as the heart and lungs.
